speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about these behavior issues you're experiencing? Are they related to your schoolwork, or do they happen more often at home with family members?

speaker: Patient
text: It's mostly at school, I just don't really like following rules and stuff, and sometimes my teacher gets really mad at me.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about what happens during these episodes when the behavior issues occur? Do you feel anxious, overwhelmed, or is it more of an impulsive reaction to certain situations?

speaker: Patient
text: It's like, I just get really frustrated when I'm not allowed to do what I want to do, and I feel like my teacher is trying to boss me around. It's hard for me to listen when I think they're not giving me a choice.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe the situations or triggers that lead to these episodes of behavior issues? Do they seem to be linked to specific events, people, or environments?

speaker: Patient
text: I guess it's mostly when my teacher tells me what to do, and I don't want to do it. It's like, I'll be doing something I like, and then they'll come over and say "stop" or "do it this way." It makes me feel like I'm being controlled.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when these episodes started? Was it a sudden change or did they develop gradually over time, and have you noticed any patterns or correlations between the episodes and things like your mood, sleep, or daily activities?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't know, it just started happening more often, I guess. My teacher says I'm being really stubborn, but I just don't see why I have to do what they say all the time.

speaker: Doctor
text: It sounds like we're starting to piece together what might be going on. I'd like to examine your hands and fingers now, please, and see if there's anything unusual going on physically that could be contributing to these behavior issues.

speaker: Patient
text: Ooh, do I have to? Can't I just talk to you some more?

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to examine your hands and fingers now. Can you show me the joints, specifically the wrists, hands, and fingers? I want to see if there's any swelling, stiffness, or unusual positioning that could be related to your symptoms.

speaker: Patient
text: Do I have to? Can't I just talk to you some more? It feels weird, like you're checking something on my hands.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you show me the joints, specifically the wrists, hands, and fingers, and are there any areas of tenderness or pain when you move your joints?



Also, when we look at your hands and fingers, I notice that the fingers on your left hand seem to be slightly shorter than the ones on your right hand. Can you tell me if you've ever had any injuries or conditions that might have affected your hand development?

text:

speaker: Patient
text:
I like playing sports during recess, like tag and soccer. I'm pretty good at soccer, but sometimes my friends tell me I'm being too competitive, and that's when I get frustrated.

I usually eat normal kid food like pizza, burgers, and sandwiches. My mom sometimes makes me eat veggies, but I don't really like those. I think they're yucky.

I'd say I have lots of energy, but sometimes I feel a little tired after a long day at school. It's not that I'm tired all the time, just some days it feels like it.

No, I don't think I've ever had a head injury. I just fell off my bike once, and it was okay. I got a scrape on my knee, but it didn't hurt that much.

Sometimes I feel really happy when I'm playing with my sister, but when I'm in class, I get a little anxious. I don't know why, it just feels weird.

speaker: Doctor
text:
